results.title: Seawards: the great ships
results.creator_credit: Hilary Harris and Templar Film Studios
results.brief_description: This documentary on the life and work of shipbuilders on Scotland’s Clyde River is historically notable as one of the last films on which John Grierson was creatively credited, preparing the outline treatment from which American Hilary Harris worked. Harris, who had previously produced interesting experimental work delivers inventive images and clever editing. Made for the Clyde Shipbuiders Association and the Films of Scotland Committee. Commentary by Bryden Murdoch. (Award: Oscar Best Short Subject/Best Live Action, 1961).

results.title: Seasonal changes in the temperate regions
results.creator_credit: Margaret Simpson, Frank Wells and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: Attention is concentrated on the temperate regions of the earth. These are shown to lie between the Tropical and Polar regions. Owing to the tilting of the earth’s axis and its movement round the sun, the temperature of these regions is very different at opposite times of the year. This point is brought out by examining the position regarding temperature in these regions in June and December. Then the two transitional seasons, in March and September, are also examined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Margaret Simpson, Frank Wells and Gaumont-British Instructional

results.title: Seaside searching
results.brief_description:
Seaside Searching consists of interviews with ‘traditional’ local residents about St Kilda and surrounds and how the area is changing, in the context of 100 years history. Speakers include working girls, homeless, welfare workers, and aboriginal residents. While the technical quality is not great, vision and sound are clear.
At first the viewer is not sure where the journey is going, and whether the speakers’ words will be enough to hold our attention given the relative lack of visual stimulation. However as the program continues we are drawn in and held by the honesty, openness and truth of what we hear. The exterior interview locations grow on the viewer as markers of place. We realise that these uneducated or unsophisticated voices are saying important and meaningful things about community, change, class and status, and how regional social change affects the individual. By the close, one likes and believes in these ‘ordinary people’, and learns the value of community voices irrespective of their apparent form.

results.title: Searchlight on the nations
results.creator_credit: Roger Barlow, Raymond Spottiswoode, Stuart Legg and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description: This film deals with the international exchange of information through modern means of communication - press, radio, films, television, telegraph, cablegram. Half the human race does not have yet the means to hear the other half; half the human race remains a prey to superstition, poverty, ignorance, disease, fallacy and distortion of the truth. This is a history of the development of communications and how the UNO is working to break down the barriers to progress and international understanding.

results.title: Search for the shark callers
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger, Maynard and Grainger Maynard
results.brief_description: A description of a two month trek by kayak through the Solomon Islands, showing the people and their culture, wildlife and tourist attractions. Experience the dying art of summon sharks with a native priest, visit steaming volcanoes and take part in pagan dances and other local ceremonies!

results.title: Search for the great apes
results.brief_description: Narrated by Richard Kiley. Deep within the rainforest of Indonesia and Central Africa, two women scientists patiently study the habits of two species of apes - Birute Galdikas-Brindamour and her husband spend their time with the orang-outang in Borneo and Dian Fossey (the inspiration for the Hollywood film, “Gorillas in the mist”) studies the mountain gorilla of Rwanda.

results.title: Search for the Battleship Bismarck
results.creator_credit: Peter Schnall, Christine Weber and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: National Geographic looks back at the first - and last- mission of the Bismarck, sunk on May 27, 1941 with a loss of more than 2,000 lives. Narrated by Richard Kiley, they talk with survivors of the notorious World War II battle, and reveals exclusive footage of the remarkable exploration for the sunken ship 600 miles off the coast of France.

results.title: Search for security
results.creator_credit: Adrian Boddington, Jennie Blackwood, Victoria. Hospitals and Charities Commission and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: A presentation of the problems facing the aged and the community’s responsibility to them. Shows through the experiences of one elderly lady (played by Lorna Forbes) the services rendered by social workers, district nurses, and “meals on wheels”. Emphasises need for companionship, warmth and comfort, as well as a degree of independence.

results.title: Search for oil
results.brief_description: ‘Search for oil’ explains some of the work involved in oil exploration prior to drilling wells. The technology is becoming increasingly complex as the search becomes more difficult, but the story is told in a simple way using interesting images from around the world with basic non-technical animated drawings. It incorporates examples of the latest advances in the field of seismic exploration.

results.title: Search for identity
results.brief_description: Presents the history of a former Cobb and Co coach house on the Old Sydney Road at Avenel in Central Victoria, from its early days in the 1850s to the present. Explores methods of research showing various techniques used to reconstruct the building’s history: visits to the Central Plans Office, Titles Office and Avenel Cemetery; and an examination of the building’s structure. Narrated bhy John Stanton.
